entry.title: In Praise of #vscocam
entry.content:
After about seven years with the same litle phone, I finally decided to upgrade. If I’m being honest, I did it because the iPhone 5S/5C camera seemed like such an improvement over the previous, and I really wanted to have access to a camera usable in ordinary situations. (My old Motorola was also starting to have problems — bad audio, bad button sensitivity.)

goodbye dear friend

The pictures that my phone takes are great — better than the pictures my old work iPod had, and definitely better than no pictures taken at all. But, what makes my silly phone photos really fun and gorgeous is the VSCO Cam app.

the foggy ferry dock on thanksgiving

You can take pictures from the app or import them, and then control expore, temperature, white balance, saturation…I have to admit, though, that it took me forever to realize that bottom bar that showed all these editing options is actually something you can scroll from left to right.

these colors were seriously bland and boring before i edited it.
and,there's that bar. it doesn't look scrollable at all.

There are also a variety of filters which, to me, are way more subtle and attractive than Instagram’s filters. I admit that I use the F2 filter way more than the others.

foggy cityline

Feel free to check out my Instagram for more photos.

the dinosaur-like cranes at the pier

entry.title: Football: Great for the Audience
entry.content:
This past weekend I finally learned about football, something I’ve never been terribly interested in. The most recent game I watched was Kind Of A Big Deal for the city I live in.

distant space needle.

It strikes me that football is an incredibly fun game to watch because the “four downs” system provides a multitude of little goals to rejoice about. Each play is rife with struggle, with a victory that can turn into loss in an instant. It reminds me of Mark Rosewater’s description of interaction and a catch-up feature as things that “every game needs.” At each “down,” both teams have the potential not just to stop each other, but to improve their own standing. It’s a powerful interval.

Watching the game this past weekend was the first time in my life that I really, finally got it. I didn’t know there were separate offensive and defensive teams; I didn’t know that there were people whose singular jobs were to run, or to kick, and that the had individual tutors. It’s pretty inspiring.

#gohawks! and, fun fact: "the 12th man" is a copyrighted phrase. a phrase not copyrighted by us.

entry.title: PAX 2013 Thoughts, & Cosplay: Red From Transistor
entry.content:
I loved Bastion and I'm super super super excited for Transistor, because it has a female protagonist with curly hair. Curly hair!

(Or at the very least, wavy hair!)

I was not keen on attending PAX this year until I found a friend selling tickets and my compulsion to hoard scarce resources broke through my skepticism of the event. I first went in 2009 and stopped out of boredom and discomfort, but decided I'd give this year another try, not because I think trivializing rape is okay (I don't) but because I wanted to see if the environment has changed since Tropes Vs Women. I also really, really, really wanted to see Transistor.

Since I got my tickets late, I started cosplay work only about a month before PAX started, which also happened to be right in the swing of summer quarter. Making the sword was fun and challenging, mostly because it was my first time working with plastic. First I made some sketches and then a model using some leftover foam from my Strength cosplay.

such cosplay wow

Then I visited TAP Plastics and after beating around the bush I admitted that I was making a giant sword. Turns out the guy staffing was also a cosplayer and happy to give me advice, which I desperately needed. I had my heart set on a blue-y transparent plastic, which they didn't have, but he explained that if I painted on the backside of clear plastic, it would look like a mirror…and that sounded great! I got a couple samples of green-edge acrylic and tried out a couple different paint colors on it.

i was so bright-eyed then

A pointed out that what would really make the sword striking would be a strong contrast between the base color and "solder lines," so for the base color I decided on using a lot of green to really make the inner lines stand out.

Then I visited TAP Plastics to get the pieces cut, and at the last moment decided I wanted not just half an inch thickness of plastic, but a whole inch. Imagine my shock and horror when I realized that such a width of plastic is actually heavy. Like, really heavy. (I don't have a scale, but a friend's estimate when he picked up the final product and grimaced was 35 lbs, so I'm going with that number.)

heavy, but still not as unwieldy as strength arms

My plan was to do a reverse painting deal on both sides of the sword and then sandwich them together. I used masking tape to copy out my drawn pattern on both sides, and first painted in the solder lines with a mixture of paints: pearly blue, shiny white, and glow-in-the-dark!

left photo courtesy of couch

I didn't get to see the glow paint in action, unfortunately, and the fact that it's sort of thick and grainy made me nervous that the plastic pieces would stick together properly when pressed together.

peeling the tape off was so satisfying

I had two circular pieces of plastic that I wanted to attach to the outside of the sword for the Transistor's red "eye," but there's also a sort of depression/border around the eye. I realized that in my limited time I wouldn't be able to do anything three-dimensional for that border, so I decided to just paint another blue circle.

dry dry dry! (also there's A, because i need another picture to even this out)

Meanwhile, the eye got the same "reverse painting" treatment.

i see you

Once the solder lines were done, I combined green-y metallic paint and blue metallic paint and painted that down across both pieces.


such contrast

Since I was swamped with making the actual costume, A helped out with the handle and cutting out what we referred to as the "top fins" and "side fins" from plywood. Because the plastic turned out to be so heavy, and because we were pressed for time, we left the handle rectangular, rather than shaved down to the canon cylinder.

plywood fins

After that, with his father's help, A and I clamped the two pieces together in a vise and drilled holes through the wood and plastic! Again not canon, but the pieces were such heavy wow, and needed that extra reinforcement.

so close!

After drilling, we had planned to take the sword apart and touch up the paint a bit, but…after all the clamping, the two pieces of plastic ended up completely stuck together. So much for worrying about it coming apart.

the light does cool shading tricks through the plastic

The last thing to be built was the pommel, which A flashed out overnight. I have no pictures of it, but it was made out of some plastic canisters and a plastic soysauce dish hot-glued together and painted over. Cosplay at its finest. :')

Finally, what was left was to paint the plywood pieces, and then glue on the red eye. A also put on some electrical tape to make the side fins appear more indented, but the tape near-immediately fell off during peace-bonding. Ah well!

done!

As for the dress itself…I reused the racer-back tank pattern I made for the Strength cosplay, though I made it longer and added a kind of cape for the sleeves. I wanted to sew the jacket as well but ran out of time and ended up compromising by sewing a satin triangle to a long black jacket I found at a consignment store a couple days before PAX. The last thing I did was the feather collar, which I made by sewing feathers into leftover Strength felt and sewing it around the dress's neck.

feathers!

On the day before PAX I also quicked out the triangular ring from Sculpey (also left over from Strength cosplay; thank goodness I can reuse so much stuff) and acrylic paint.

photo by couch

Sooo overall…though there are a couple things I want to re-do for the next round (including remaking the feather collar and ring), I finished a new cosplay and am proud of my new forays into the world of plastic! PAX itself was fun in and of itself; I was really happy to finally play Transistor, and even more excited for it once I actually played and recognized all the programming nods. I was a little bewildered by the inclusion of the "stop time and attack" thing, until I realized it was so thematic — since the Transistor's atacks are sort of like methods, "stopping time" to queue up attacks and execute them really mirrors compiling programs. Uwaaa.

I was also surprised and happy to see so many cool Reds at PAX, many of whom had taken the extra leap to use ~*electricity*~! I briefly ran into the Red from Breakers Cosplay who was super impressive and inspiring. I also met a lot of progressive dudes and women who specifically talked about how awesome it is to have A Female Protagonist in a game (something I don't think I would have never heard anyone say flat-out in years past), and a lot of friendly people in general who gamely attempted holding my Transistor and remarked at how they admired my ridiculousness for carrying it around all day at the convention, haha. To be fair, my arms were really sore afterward, but all my rock climbing callouses helped out quite a bit!

My favorite moment in all of PAX was to meet Jen Zee, who was so awesome and kind and asked for pictures in which I tried desperately to look cool despite my euphoria. She also gave me a ton of Supergiant swag that I placed all around my house immediately. :')

i christen thee, supergiant wall

There was also a magical instant where A and I, passing curiously by the Paramount, suddenly realized that Darren Korb and Ashley Barrett were performing and dashed inside as quickly as possible and caught the Transistor song!

All this being said, I had a great weekend, mostly due to the friends and people I was able to meet. I don't think I feel comfortable enough to return again (because reasons), but I am thankful for my personal experience this year.

especially for time runnin around with couch!

And finally, now that both my summer quarter classes and PAX are completely finished, I am free!

…and ready to devote myself to a new project! Maybe something for the Tower Jam?

Comments

cosbabyfive
Several hundred years ago, humans were nearly exterminated by giants. Giants are typically several stories tall, seem to have no intelligence, devour human beings and, worst of all, seem to do it for the pleasure rather than as a food source. Love this AoT anime, love the Attack on Titan cosplay costumes in www.cosplayfield.com!

entry.title: May Garden/Growing Update: Radishes, Blueberries, Tillandsia, Succulents, & Etc.
entry.content:
Garden stuff has been progressing without me writing much about it because recently I am lucky if I can manage to wake up early enough or stay up long enough at home to water anything, much less take photos of it and muse upon its growth. Suffice to say that at the start of spring I went crazy over some on-sale seeds and attempted to plant some in seed starter pots.

march pots

Dragon's Tongue Wax Beans in particular looked super cool and exciting and got off to a great start indoors…

lil things

…but when I transplanted them outside, they didn't last two weeks. Maybe I didn't harden them off enough? Maybe, like swiss chard, they're too delicate to withstand transplanting? When I transplanted them I also planted some new beans, and these happen to be doing really well. Unlike the indoor starts, they have very deep green leaves and thick stems.

transplants in the back, new beans in the front

My other surprise is the success of my radishes, which I planted outdoors in March alongside some arugula and swiss chard. Look, they're doing it! They're really growing!

radishes

They're probably the most attractive-looking edible thing I've grown this far, especially since the spinach and swiss chard I started growing before last winter tasted pretty mediocre. My mistake was not staggering out their sowing, however, so I pretty much just have this batch and that's it for now.

Speaking of the spinach, as soon as the heat started getting up to around 70 degrees Fahrenheit, they started sending up flowers. The plants rise up over my knee now, and their stalks are as thick as my fingers, and it's hard to believe that they used to be just little seeds.

biiig spinaches

My lime tree has really perked up now that the weather has gotten better, though has still suffered from leaves that are pale green and strangely droopy and bendy. They feel almost elastic. Some internet research has uncovered that I, in my passion to not drown it, I may be under watering it. Since being given a couple thorough soaks, the leaves indeed seem a little stiffer and greener. I've also repotted it into something larger and more sturdy than its initial black pot. No flowers or fruit yet, probably because it's been stressed and dehydrated for the better part of its life with me.



Speaking of stressed and dehydrated, before the winter started Andou and I received a very impressive-looking 30 year old jade tree...

jade tree on the sunniest part of our house, the laundry room

I was very concerned about killing it, especially since, despite my diligent watering, its leaves began to fall off in gooey yellow curls. Some internet research has uncovered that I, in my passion to not kill it, I was probably over watering it. I've since then toned down and the tree seems okay on its new perch over the dryer. One branch even bloomed little white blossoms! Whoa!

My air plants from last year are doing well. In the picture below, the top plant had one pup that is now fairly large, and the bottom actually had two pups, so it's getting to be a handful.

spot the pups!

It's been about a year since I got them at the UW Street Fair, and when the fair rolled around again this weekend I was excited to pick up more! Four more, in fact. I was excited to get ones with weirder tentacle shapes, and then also picked up two teensy blooming ones, one of which already looks like it's growing a pup. The two little ones are already a year old and were blooming already, so it makes me a little bewildered about why my plants from last year are not blooming. Maybe I should invest in some fertilizer.

spot the pup!

Speaking of plants retrieved at fairs, my sedums are doing okay. The iceplant-looking one is faring the best of all of them. I've moved three of them to a little pot I bought at Daiso and tried to give them succulent soil to see if they would do any better than in normal potting soil, but thus far I don't observe any difference.

sedums in a long pot

Speaking of succulent soil, the reason why I had some is because I got another succulent! I saw it on sale at the hardware store and couldn't resist. Donkey/burro tail plants are so neat-looking. Some of the little bean-leaves had detached and fallen between into the dirt inside the pot, so I took them out and placed them in their own pots to see if they might grow into new plants.

burro tail on the dryer

And that's (almost) all of what I have growing.

entry.title: Selesnya Hat
entry.content:
with bonus ears

Hat! Fleece! Felt! The tree came out a little lopsided but I think it was good for a first try. I intended for it to have more of a chullo-shape but in the end confused myself and ended up just going back to the familiar rectangular shape the yields triangle ears.

I have a lot more brown and white fleece left which I hope to use for future corgi- or shiba-related endeavors!
